metadata.titleEn: 3-D thermal regime and petrologic metamorphism beneath Izu-Bonin Arc
metadata.description: The data includes the three-dimensional temperature field (degrees Celsius), water content (wt%), dehydration rate (wt%/km), rock phase change distribution, and subduction velocity field (cm/yr) of the subducting plate, as well as the coastline and volcano distribution in Izu-Bonin. The data coordinates are temporarily an orthogonal coordinate system, where the origin of the coordinates is (142.60E, 30.00N), the x+ azimuth is 83 degrees clockwise from the north, the y+ azimuth is 353 degrees clockwise from the north, and the z+ direction is vertical downwards, in kilometers. The data source method is a three-dimensional finite-difference numerical simulation. The geophysical calculation is ensured after the subduction thermal regime reaches a steady state. The temperature field error range is ±10 degrees Celsius, and the velocity field error range is ±0.1cm/ yr. This data can be used to further analyze the geophysical field of the subduction zone.
metadata.instructions:
File naming: the data is stored in text paraview format. 
Data reading method: All ASCII code files in the data set can be directly opened with paraview software.

literatureList.titleEn: Thermal regime and slab dehydration beneath the Izu-Bonin arc: Implications for fast and slow subduction earthquakes
literatureList.referenceEn: Zhu, W.L., Ji, Y.F., Qu, R., Xie, C.D., Yoshioka S., & Zeng, D. (2021). Thermal regime and slab dehydration beneath the Izu-Bonin arc: Implications for fast and slow subduction earthquakes. Terra Nova, 34(2), 103-112. https://doi.org/10.1111/ter.12568.

fundVOList.titleEn: Second Tibetan Plateau Scientific Expedition and Research Programme (STEP)

projectList.titleEn: National Tibetan Plateau / Third Pole Environment Data Center

background: The Izu-Bonin arc, together with the Marina arc, represents the typical mode of an intra-oceanic convergent margin, and subduction in this region has been consuming some of the oldest seafloor on the planet for 43 Ma (Klemperer, 2003). The Izu-Bonin margin is composed of thick sediments and numerous seamounts (Oakley et al., 2008; Yamamoto et al., 2009) with a chain of serpentine seamounts exposed at the forearc slope 40–50 km west of the Izu-Bonin Trench axis (Kamimura et al., 2002). Teleseismic double-difference P-wave tomography was used to image the structural complexity of a tear in the Izu-Bonin slab between 26.5°N and 28°N with unprecedented clarity (Zhao et al., 2017). The deep earthquakes in this region have been caused by the effects of several factors, such as fast slab subduction, slab tearing, slab thermal variations, stress changes and phase transformations in the slab, and complex interactions between the slab and the ambient mantle (e.g., Zhao et al., 2017; Zhang et al., 2019).
research objective: Therefore, this study attempts to focus on the three-dimensional (3-D) slab thermal state and hydraulic distribution in Izu-Bonin and to investigate the distributions of observed fast and slow earthquakes on the megathrusts.
challenges: However, the subduction thermal regime responsible for generating seismic and aseismic slip on the subducted Pacific plate in the Izu-Bonin arc remains enigmatic, which is fundamental to the transition from the cold forearc to hot arc and the range and depth of the cold nose.
methods: To characterize the Izu-Bonin megathrust and its geographically distributed hydrothermal state, we constructed a 3-D, time-evolving thermomechanical model developed from Stag3D code (Tackley & Xie, 2003) for the Izu-Bonin subduction zone. The model region has dimensions of 1000 × 500 × 400 km3 (length × width × depth) that simulate the simultaneous penetration of the incoming plate over 15 Myr. The geometry of the subducted plate is well constrained by Slab2.0 (Hayes et al., 2018), and it is extrapolated within the modelled domain to ensure full subduction and comparatively steady slab thermal conditions (Figures 2 and 3). Based on the thermomechanical models, we focus on the hydrothermal regime in Izu-Bonin and the distributions of fast and slow megathrust earthquakes.
findings: The cold nose in Izu-Bonin is constrained to the depth of approximately 60 km, which is between the arc and the Moho-depth plate interface with a variation in depth along the arc. The spatially changing multilayered hydrothermal regime shows that dehydration embrittlement resulting from the eclogitization and harzburgitization of subducted rocks greatly influences the occurrence of fast to slow earthquakes. The lowered temperature (<1000°C) and delay of rock harzburgitization in the cold centremost part of subducted Pacific plate at depth contribute to the occurrence of deep earthquakes below the hot backarc interface.

Verification.Question: Is a three-dimensional thermomechanical model used as a method for data collection in analyzing the Izu-Bonin subduction zone?
Does the data collection method involve using finite difference numerical simulation to achieve a steady-state physical calculation for the subduction zone?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the primary data collection method for studying the Izu-Bonin subduction zone based on three-dimensional finite difference numerical simulation, teleseismic P-wave tomography, or other techniques?

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection methods are employed to obtain the three-dimensional temperature field and rock phase transition distribution in the Izu-Bonin subduction zone?
Who might benefit from using a dataset that includes subduction velocity field, coastline, and volcano distribution for geophysical analysis?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to model the 3-D thermal state and hydraulic distribution in a subduction zone?
Example.Answer: A 3-D, time-evolving thermomechanical model developed from Stag3D code was used to simulate the Izu-Bonin subduction zone's thermal state and hydraulic distribution over 15 Myr, as geographically constrained by Slab2.0.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a challenge faced when modeling subduction thermal regimes in intra-oceanic convergent margins?
Example.Answer: One challenge is understanding the subduction thermal regime responsible for generating seismic and aseismic slip, which is fundamental to the transition from the cold forearc to hot arc and the depth variation of the cold nose.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset or model input that could enhance the understanding of fast and slow earthquake distributions in a subduction zone?
Example.Answer: The dataset could include the three-dimensional temperature field, hydraulic distribution, and seismic data to analyze the spatially changing multilayered hydrothermal regime and its influence on the occurrence of fast to slow earthquakes.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the three-dimensional temperature field and rock phase transformations in subduction zones?
Feature Specification.Answer: temperature field in Celsius, water content (wt%), dehydration rate (wt%/km), distribution of rock phase transformations, error range of ±50°C

Feature Specification.Question: What specific features define the geographical coordinate system used for data collection in subduction zone research?
Feature Specification.Answer: 142.60E, 30.00N, x+ direction 83 degrees clockwise from north, y+ direction 353 degrees clockwise from north, z+ direction vertically downward, measured in kilometers

Quantification.Question: What is the size of the model region used to simulate the Izu-Bonin subduction zone in a thermomechanical model?
How long is the simulation period for the thermomechanical model used to analyze the Izu-Bonin megathrust?

Definition.Question: What does 'three-dimensional finite difference numerical simulation' refer to in the context of data collection for subduction zones?
Definition.Answer: Three-dimensional finite difference numerical simulation is a data collection method used to model complex geological phenomena, such as the subduction of tectonic plates. It involves discretizing a three-dimensional space into a grid and solving physical equations to simulate processes like temperature distribution, rock phase changes, and fluid movement over time. This method allows researchers to predict and analyze the thermal and mechanical behavior of subduction zones, providing detailed insights into the underlying geophysical fields.

Definition.Question: What does 'hydrothermal regime' mean when analyzing megathrust earthquakes in subduction zones?
Definition.Answer: The 'hydrothermal regime' refers to the distribution and movement of fluids and their thermal properties within a subduction zone, particularly along megathrust faults. It involves the study of water content, dehydration processes, and fluid-induced changes in rock properties, which can influence seismic activity. Understanding the hydrothermal regime helps in analyzing the occurrence and characteristics of fast and slow megathrust earthquakes, as fluid presence and movement can alter stress conditions and affect the mechanical behavior of the subducted plate.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in the data collection challenges between constructing a 3-D thermomechanical model for the Izu-Bonin subduction zone and analyzing the hydrothermal regime using observational data?
Comparison.Answer: Constructing a 3-D thermomechanical model involves numerical simulation challenges, requiring accurate representation of slab geometry and subduction processes over time, whereas analyzing the hydrothermal regime using observational data involves challenges in capturing complex interactions and variability in seismic events and hydration states through observational techniques.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in accurately modeling the subduction thermal regime responsible for seismic and aseismic slip in the Izu-Bonin arc?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges arise due to the complex nature of the subduction thermal regime, which influences the transition from the cold forearc to the hot arc, as well as the range and depth of the cold nose. These complexities make it difficult to accurately model and understand the interactions and resulting seismic activities in the region.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is constructing a three-dimensional thermomechanical model crucial for understanding the hydrothermal regime and earthquake distribution in the Izu-Bonin subduction zone?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Constructing a three-dimensional thermomechanical model is crucial because it allows researchers to simulate the subduction process over time, capturing the thermal and mechanical interactions within the zone. This model helps in understanding the hydrothermal state and the geographic distribution of fast and slow earthquakes, providing insights into the underlying processes driving seismicity.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of utilizing a three-dimensional finite difference numerical simulation method for collecting data on the subduction thermal regime of the Izu-Bonin arc?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing a three-dimensional finite difference numerical simulation method allows for a detailed and dynamic representation of the subduction thermal regime. This approach could result in a more accurate understanding of the thermal conditions and phase transformations within the slab, which are crucial for analyzing the geophysical field of the subduction zone.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the implications of including data on rock phase transitions within the subducted Pacific plate when analyzing the cold nose phenomenon in the Izu-Bonin arc?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Including data on rock phase transitions within the subducted Pacific plate can provide a more comprehensive view of the cold nose phenomenon. It highlights the role of eclogitization and harzburgitization processes in influencing the thermal state and seismic activities, particularly in understanding the depth and extent of the cold nose and its relation to earthquake occurrences.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of constructing a 3-D thermomechanical model for analyzing the Izu-Bonin subduction zone?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The purpose is to characterize the Izu-Bonin megathrust and its geographically distributed hydrothermal state and to investigate the distributions of observed fast and slow earthquakes on the megathrusts.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it significant to focus on the three-dimensional slab thermal state and hydraulic distribution in the Izu-Bonin region?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Focusing on these aspects is significant because the subduction thermal regime is fundamental to understanding the transition from cold forearc to hot arc and the range and depth of the cold nose, which remains enigmatic in this region.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind using teleseismic double-difference P-wave tomography in studying the Izu-Bonin slab?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to image the structural complexity of a tear in the Izu-Bonin slab with unprecedented clarity, which helps in understanding the factors causing deep earthquakes, such as slab subduction, tearing, thermal variations, stress changes, and phase transformations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can a three-dimensional thermomechanical model be developed to simulate the slab thermal state and hydraulic distribution in a subduction zone like the Izu-Bonin area?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To develop a three-dimensional thermomechanical model for simulating the slab thermal state and hydraulic distribution in a subduction zone like Izu-Bonin, researchers can utilize a code such as Stag3D. The model would have dimensions of 1000 × 500 × 400 km3 and simulate the penetration of the incoming plate over 15 Myr. The geometry of the subducted plate can be constrained using data from sources like Slab2.0, and then extrapolated within the model to ensure full subduction and steady slab thermal conditions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to determine the distributions of fast and slow earthquakes on megathrusts in regions like the Izu-Bonin arc?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The distributions of fast and slow earthquakes on megathrusts can be determined by constructing a 3-D, time-evolving thermomechanical model that captures the hydrothermal regime of the subduction zone. This involves analyzing the spatially changing multilayered hydrothermal regime and understanding the dehydration embrittlement processes due to eclogitization and harzburgitization of subducted rocks, which influence seismic activities.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological approaches can be employed to accurately model the subduction velocity field and temperature distribution in a subduction zone?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To accurately model the subduction velocity field and temperature distribution, researchers can employ a three-dimensional finite difference numerical simulation. This simulation should calculate physical values after the subduction has reached a steady state. The model should account for the error margins, such as ±50°C for temperature fields and ±0.1 cm/yr for velocity fields, to enhance the accuracy of the geophysical analysis.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the simulation of three-dimensional temperature fields and rock phase transitions in subduction zones?
Enablement.Answer: The data collection method involves three-dimensional finite difference numerical simulation to calculate the physical values after the subduction reaches a steady state. The simulation provides insights into the temperature fields, hydration and dehydration rates, and rock phase transitions in the subduction zone.

Enablement.Question: How do thermomechanical models contribute to understanding the hydrothermal state and earthquake distributions in subduction zones?
Enablement.Answer: Thermomechanical models, such as those developed using the Stag3D code, simulate the subduction dynamics over geological timescales, allowing researchers to characterize the hydrothermal regime and the distribution of fast and slow megathrust earthquakes. These models are informed by structural data like the geometry of the subducted plate and its thermal conditions.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in accurately simulating the thermal regime responsible for seismic and aseismic slip in subducted plates using current data collection methods?
Expectation.Answer: The subduction thermal regime remains enigmatic due to the complexity of factors involved, such as fast slab subduction, slab tearing, thermal variations, and phase transformations. These factors contribute to the difficulty in simulating the thermal regime accurately, as they require intricate modeling of interactions between the slab and the ambient mantle.

Expectation.Question: What are the potential reasons for the absence of datasets that specifically address the distribution of fast and slow earthquakes on megathrusts in subduction zones?
Expectation.Answer: The absence of such datasets may be due to the complexity of capturing the hydrothermal regime and its spatial variation in subduction zones. The need for high-resolution three-dimensional models that consider time-evolving thermomechanical processes could be a limiting factor, as such data is crucial for understanding the distribution of fast and slow earthquakes.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of using three-dimensional finite difference numerical simulations for modeling the subduction zone's temperature and rock phase transformations?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of three-dimensional finite difference numerical simulations is effective in modeling complex subduction zone processes, as it allows for the detailed representation of temperature fields and rock phase transformations. This method supports the analysis of geophysical fields and can accommodate the spatial variability and dynamics inherent in subduction zones.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what potential does the integration of a 3-D thermomechanical model hold for understanding the hydrothermal regime and earthquake distributions in subduction zones?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating a 3-D thermomechanical model holds significant potential for understanding the hydrothermal regime and earthquake distributions in subduction zones. It allows researchers to simulate the interactions between thermal and mechanical processes over time, providing insights into the conditions leading to different earthquake types and the spatial distribution of hydrothermal systems.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out how three-dimensional finite difference numerical simulations are employed to gather data for subduction zones.
Assertion.Answer: Three-dimensional finite difference numerical simulations are used to model physical parameters such as temperature, water content, dehydration rate, and velocity fields over time. These simulations allow researchers to estimate the subduction zone's steady-state conditions and understand the spatial distribution of geological features like temperature fields and phase transitions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore and explain different data collection methods for modeling the three-dimensional thermal state and hydraulic distribution in subduction zones like Izu-Bonin.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection method for modeling the three-dimensional thermal state and hydraulic distribution in subduction zones such as Izu-Bonin involves constructing a 3-D, time-evolving thermomechanical model. This model is developed from the Stag3D code and simulates the penetration of the incoming plate over millions of years. It requires well-constrained geometry of the subducted plate, as seen in Slab2.0, to ensure accurate subduction modeling and steady slab thermal conditions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and discuss the primary challenges encountered in collecting and modeling data for subduction thermal regimes responsible for generating seismic and aseismic slip.
Request/Directive.Answer: The primary challenge in collecting and modeling data for subduction thermal regimes responsible for generating seismic and aseismic slip in regions like Izu-Bonin is understanding the complex interactions between the slab and the ambient mantle. The subduction thermal regime is enigmatic, particularly in transitioning from the cold forearc to hot arc and determining the range and depth of the cold nose, which influences earthquake occurrences.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that could be utilized to analyze the spatially changing multilayered hydrothermal regimes and their effect on earthquake occurrences in subduction zones.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for analyzing spatially changing multilayered hydrothermal regimes and their effect on earthquake occurrences include the three-dimensional temperature field, hydration and dehydration rates, subduction velocity field, and distribution of rock phase transformations. These datasets can be derived from three-dimensional finite difference numerical simulations and are critical for understanding the dehydration embrittlement processes and thermal conditions influencing fast to slow earthquakes.
